awd_titl_txt: Active Scalar Equations and a Geodynamo Model
awd_abstract_narration:
Active scalar equations describe a number of physical phenomena that arise in fluid dynamics. Because of their physical importance and challenging mathematical nature there is a very extensive literature on such equations. However, many problems connected with the nonlinearity of the equation remain open, particularly when the drift velocity U is nonlocal. This project addresses some of these questions with particular emphasis on examples where the operator M that encodes the physics of the problem relating U to the active scalar is singular and unbounded. It is proposed to study the interplay of diffusive effects and the nonlinearity in singular active scalar equations for a range of fractional powers of the Laplacian. For certain powers it will be shown that the system is nonlinearly unstable: for lower powers the system is Lipschitz ill-posed. These results will be obtained via the construction of unstable eigenvalues for the evolution equation linearised about an appropriate equilibrium. Techniques of continued fractions will be employed to produce an explicit lower bound on the growth rate of the unstable eigenvalues as a function of the physical parameters. The project will also study the highly singular limit of vanishing  diffusivity. This limit is often physically appropriate and may be closely connected with turbulent phenomena modeled by weak solutions of the active scalar equations. The project addresses general classes of active scalar equations: particular physical examples include the incompressible porous media equation and the magnetogeostrophic equation. In both examples the Fourier multiplier symbol for the relevant operator M is even with respect to the wave number vector. This prevents certain cancellations in energy estimates arising in the nonlinearity. Hence the problem is more subtle than some frequently studied equations, such as the surface quasigeostrophic equation, where the analogous Fourier multiplier symbol is odd and commutator estimates can be employed.

The mathematical study of the partial differential equations that model fluid motion forms an essential foundation for many applications. These equations are highly complex and challenging.  A subset of these equations are so-called "active scalar equations" where the evolution in time of a scalar quantity such as the density of the fluid is governed by the motion of the fluid where the velocity itself varies with this scalar field. This feedback produces an intricate nonlinearity. Friedlander uses techniques of "hard" analysis to study general classes of such equations. A particular example is a model for the geodynamo. This is the process by which the Earth's magnetic field is created and sustained through the motion of the fluid core which is composed of a rapidly rotating, density stratified, electrically conducting fluid. Friedlander will prove that the model can indeed produce dynamo action by demonstrating the existence of a strong instability whose growth rate can be bounded from below by an explicit expression that depends on the physical parameters of the Earth's fluid core.

por.por_cntn:
Susan Friedlander furthered national priorities through her analysis of
the mathematical description of the geodynamo and magnetostrophic
turbulence. The source of the Earth's magnetic field is deep inside the
Earth where a small solid iron center is surrounded by a huge spherical
mass of electrically conducting liquid iron. Convection in this liquid is
the origin of the Earth's magnetic field through a dynamo effect. A
mathematical description of this phenomenon is crucial to further our
understanding of our planet, however the appropriate mathematics is a
highly complex system of three dimensional, nonlinear partial differential
equations. Friedlander and her collaborators focused on an interesting
active scalar equation that was proposed by Moffatt and Loper as a model
for magnetostrophic turbulence in the context of the geodynamo. In the
period covered by this grant Friedlander and her co-authors published 11
research articles in major journals concerning this topic.

Specific results include the following novel mathematics. Friedlander and
Vicol investigated the subtle balance between nonlinearity and diffusion
by studying a general class of critically diffusive parabolic partial
differential equations with singular drift velocities. They proved global
regularity for a family of active scalar equations. Once well-posedness
was determined they showed that the Moffatt-Loper model did indeed support
dynamo type instabilities. The nondiffusive equation is dramatically
different from the critically diffusive case. Without the Laplacian to
control the nonlinear term, Friedlander and Vicol proved that the model is
ill-posed in the sense of Hadamard.

Friedlander incorporates her research in her teaching and seminars to
assist in the training of students and postdocs. In addition to Vlad Vicol,
who was a postdoc at the time of the work described above, Friedlander
mentored other postdocs and involved them with the projects supported by
this grant. Her early career co-authors included Roman Shvydkoy, Alexey
Cheskidov, Walter Rusin, Anthony Suen, and Nathan Glatt-Holtz. During the
period of this grant she gave many invited lectures, seminars and
colloquia at national and international venues including workshops on
various aspects of fluid dynamics.

Friedlander is engaged in many professional activities with broader
impact for the mathematical community and society. She is the Director of
the Center for Applied Mathematical Sciences at the University of Southern
California which plays an active role in fostering research and education
in applicable mathematics. CAMS holds a very active colloquium series on a
broad range of topics and which are frequently co-sponsored by science and
engineering departments. Students are strongly encouraged to participate
in these seminars.Friedlander oversees such activities as career advice
panels and the awarding of USC wide graduate student prizes for excellence
in research with a substantial mathematical component.

As Editor in Chief of the Bulletin of the American Mathematical Society,
Friedlander ensures that this prestigious journal has an excellent level
of exposition in order to inform a diverse and broad audience about
cutting edge developments in mathematical research.  She is also a member
of the editorial boards of three other highly regarded journals covering a
number of areas in applied mathematics.

Friedlander is playing a major role in the creation of a multinational
organization, the Mathematical Council of the Americas, whose role is to
foster scientific integration between mathematical communities in North
America and Latin America. She was one of the main organizers of the first
Mathematical Congress of the Americas which took place in Mexico in 2013.

In 2012 the impacts of Friedlander's research, dissemination and mentoring
activities were recognized by her election as Fellow of three professional
societies, namely the American Mathematical Society, the Society for
Industrial and Applied Mathematics and the American Association for the
Advancement of Science.
